sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Good afternoon and welcome to Euronews Now. It's Friday the 14th of January.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: I'm Andrea Bolaito. Here are your top stories this hour.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Poland warns the risk of war in Europe is the highest it's been in decades after a week of diplomatic talks failed to ease tensions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Tennis number one Novak Djokovic is facing deportation from Australia

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: as his visa is revoked for a second time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And Britain's Prince Andrew is stripped of his military and royal titles as he fights allegations of sexual assault.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: titles as he fights allegations of sexual assault. No breakthrough. That's how a third round of diplomatic talks between NATO and Russia have concluded at the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe in Vienna. Poland, which chaired the meeting, warned that Europe is at risk of plunging into war. The White House National Security Adviser said the risk of a Russian invasion of Ukraine was high.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We've now completed an intensive week of diplomacy in multiple formats.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Russia raised its concerns.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We raised our concerns, including the actions Russia has taken to undermine European security.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We're prepared to continue with diplomacy to advance security and stability in the Euro-Atlantic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: We're equally prepared if Russia chooses a different path." The Russian deputy foreign minister refused to rule out the possibility of sending military

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: assets to Cuba and Venezuela if NATO doesn't stop military activities on Russia's doorstep. The Russian president has spoken many times on this subject in particular, what the military actions should be within the Russian Navy if anything goes towards provoking Russia and the further enhancement of military pressure from the US side. We don't want this. Diplomats must negotiate.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Jamie Shea is a former NATO Deputy Assistant Secretary General.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: He says what happens next is up to Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The ball is in Putin's court.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Is he interested in a dialogue, in some kind of negotiation, or is all of this posturing on the Russian side to maximize unacceptable demands, not seek any solution, and then simply use a failure of talks, which were doomed to fail in any way, as a pretext to invade Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Lithuania shares a border with Russia, and it says the threat of war is greater than at any time since 1945. Now it's preparing for the worst.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Men's number one tennis player Novak Djokovic has once again had his Australian visa revoked.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The decision was taken by immigration minister Alex Hawke, citing health and good order.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: In a statement, Hawke said it was also within the public interest.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Djokovic now faces deportation and a ban from Australia for three years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: His chances of defending his title at the Australian Open are also now in peril.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: However, the 34-year-old Serb can still launch another legal appeal to remain in the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The player's visa was first revoked on the 6th of January due to what authorities called failure to provide appropriate evidence to receive a Covid-19 vaccine exemption.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: It was later understood that Djokovic had tested positive for the virus in mid-December and broke isolation rules.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: There were also errors on his entry forms that he blamed on his manager.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: To discuss what this means for the Serbian player and the Australian Open, I'm joined by Euronews sports correspondent Michael Kern. Hi, thanks very much for being on the programme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So first off, what do we know? What do we know about what's happening with Djokovic and the visa right now? Okay, so this is pretty much breaking and adapting as we kind of go along this morning.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So effectively what's happened at 6pm last night in Australian time, it's not too long ago, they were served papers to say effectively that his visa has been revoked for a second time. The immigration minister, Alex Hawke, who we know has been considering this for the last few days, said, today I've exercised my power to cancel the visa held by Mr. Novak Djokovic on health and good order grounds. So what this effectively means now that he can be deported, he can be banned from Australia for three years. But of course, he has the right for appeal. The competition starts Monday. So it's a very difficult task for Novak's lawyers to get something in place, in process, to enable Monday to happen. There's not been an official word yet of whether he can still play, whatever happens. As I said, it's kind of evolving as we go along. But I've seen a comment from a Melbourne-based immigration lawyer who said that basically it's going to be an incredibly difficult task for court orders over the weekend to be issued to allow him to play next week. So, look, this is evolving as we go along. And I think a massively concerning thing is the fact that we're a few days out from the first massive grand slam of the year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We're not talking about all those players that are training incredibly hard to win the title.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We're still talking about Novak Djokovic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And if this rumbles on even further, we'll still be talking about him all the way through the tournament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Clearly, this has been very detrimental for Djokovic himself but how has how has you know competitive tennis the ATP in particular come out of this as well? Do you know I think it's very very interesting there's some been comments on Twitter which I took note of the last couple of days was was how he's been treated as kind of he's not been cast aside, there's not been comments out saying that he's done wrong and kind of vindicating him. Whereas we look back a couple of years ago when Naomi Osaka missed some press conferences and when she kind of took some time out for her own mental well-being, the kind of support wasn't there as much. So there's some real questions I think that are going to be asked around tennis and the sports reaction from inside to all of this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And of course, there's legal aspects to this as well, which we, of course, have to be very careful of and very sensitive of as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So it's not an easy issue. It's a complex issue.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But yeah, I think a lot of people are starting to lose a bit of patience, should we say, if you look on social media towards the whole situation journalists military police preparing here for the noon funeral the final farewell to David Sassoli president of the European Parliament who died earlier this week his final farewell a funeral, will take place here at the Church of St Mary and the Angels at the Piazza della Repubblica here in the centre of Rome.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: He lay in state yesterday at the Capitol House where hundreds of mourners paid their final respects and expressed a sorrow at his death. We've heard moving tributes from the likes of former Prime Minister of Italy Enrico Letta, who said that he was someone who protected democracy during the challenging and dark days of the coronavirus pandemic. His funeral today will be attended by Presidents of the European Commission Ursula von der Leyen and President of the European Council Charles Michel, as well as his former colleagues in the Democratic Party of Italy and in the European Parliament. Shona Murray, Rome.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: and in the European Parliament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Shona Murray, Rome.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Britain's Prince Andrew has been stripped of his honorary military titles and his royal patronages have been returned to the Queen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Earlier this week, a US judge ruled that a sexual assault case against the British royal could go ahead.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: In a statement, Buckingham Palace announced that the Duke of York, who denies the allegations, will defend his case as a private citizen and will not be undertaking any public duties. Royal commentator Richard Fitzwilliams told Euronews that the Queen had little choice but to distance herself and the monarchy from the scandal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: It was undoubtedly the right decision at the beginning of her Platinum Jubilee year, but also in response to some anger from veterans and also to a lengthy catalogue of what I can only describe as catastrophic mistakes by Andrew.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: All the options open to him, whether he ignores the court, which is in New York, whether he attempts a settlement, which could be seen as part of his admission of guilt if it can be negotiated, or if he were actually to take part in some form of court trial, all of these look bad for him, as does his behaviour and his choice of friends, including that grotesque interview on BBC News Night in November 2019.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Stay with us. More top stories to come on Euronews, or catch up with all the day's news on our website. That's Euronews.com.
